problem_text:
A subgroup H of a group G is called 2-infinitely isolated in G if, whenever the centralizer C_G(h) in G of some element h ≠ 1 of H contains at least one involution and intersects H in an infinite subgroup, it follows that C_G(h) ⩽ H. Let G be an infinite simple locally finite group whose Sylow 2-subgroups are Chernikov groups, and suppose G has a proper 2-infinitely isolated subgroup H containing some Sylow 2-subgroup of G. Does it follow that G is isomorphic to a group of the type PSL2(k), where k is a field of odd characteristic?
V. P. Shunkov
answer: Yes, it does (V. P. Shunkov, Algebra and Logic, 11 (1972), 260–272).
